author: {'steamid': '76561198263427469', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1507475013}
review:
A good idea for the game with mediocre realisation and a lack of content

This game is a mix of TD and Arcade genres. From Tower Defense games it got point A, where enemies come from, and a target B, which they are trying to destroy. This game also contains "towers", which are not towers, but units, which follow your "Bard". 

So the goal of the game is eliminate 20 waves of enemies moving your hero as a locomotive, while your units are killing enemies without your manual control. Despite moving and hiring new units you can also collect droppable items, like gold or notes (in game currency) and use powerups. I think.. that's all, what you can do in the battle... and, actually, it's enough to be satisfied..... enough until you die.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1162513909

After the death, you appear in the loddy room, where you can upgrade your hero, troops and base using gold, which was dropped from the killed enemies in the battle. Each unit has 7 upgrades, there 20+ units. But only a few available at the start. Also, there are 10 upgrades for your hero with 2-5 levels and 6 upgrades with 2-5 levels for the base. In my opinion, it's a good addition to the game.

When you finished with upgrades you start the game and.... you appear at the level 1... again. Even if you passed Level 4 in the last session... you start from Level 1.... And that's the great problem with this game. It's incredible repetitive game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1162514042

So, actually I wanted to play further, but I didn't want to play the same levels again and again for just getting gold and I had not enough unit power to beat the next level.So... sorry, but I appreciate my time.

There are also two mine-games. First mode is endless run, classic arcade, you run until you die :D
The second is similar to main gameplay. The main difference you protect nothing except you. You will get new new unit every 20-30s. So, just run and survive.

Both modes weren't interesting for me.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1162513825

[b]Pros[/b]
- Interesting idea of the gameplay
- Nice sound design
- No bugs were found
- Cheap game

[b]Cons[/b]
- Every session starts from the beginning of the stage. There are 4 stages with 5 levels in each one. So even if you passed 4 levels and get killed by the boss in the 5th level, you are forced to play about 15 minutes in the first 4 levels before you can give him a revanche.
- It's impossible to complete the game from the first try, because your squade is weak. So you need to replay the game again and again before you will be strong enough to kill the boss on the 20th level.
- The game looks the same during all 20 waves
- Annoying delay when Bard performs 5s guitar solo after each unit summoning or using ability
- Unbalanced difficulty curve. 1-4 levels are extremely easy ( and boring because of it), but when boss comes and wipes you out in a couple of seconds....

[h1]Resume[/h1]
A nice idea for the game which was spoiled with insanely grind system and repetitive gameplay. I can't recommend it.
developer_response:
Hi, just a note, once you reach wave 5 you can begin from there. Sounds like you just didn't quite make the checkpoint! Also, if you want a quicker track through the game, we recommend playing on Insane, it offers more gold & more challenge.
Cheers,

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359498', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1505030287}
review:
When building a new game in saturated genres, indie developers reach pretty far to find some impressive concepts to implement that make their game stand out.  With Bardbarian it seems like the most interesting part of the game, the idea that this warrior is using music as his weapon, is left behind – making the title itself less descriptive of the game than the generic genres it crosses over.

[h1]Rock me like a boricane[/h1]

The title “Bardbarian” had me thinking I was going to see something heavily related to music, maybe even a rhythm game.  After watching the trailer I saw that it was a good bit different from that, but I figured it would at least involve a little more player involvement than I ultimately discovered.  The primary goal of the game is the defense of a crystal, so the premise is essentially a tower defense game.  You play the role of the Bardbarian who takes up this defensive goal, except you as a character have virtually no direct influence on the invading enemies that seek to destroy the town's crystal.  You instead play guitar riffs (which consume the resource you build over time playing your guitar) that recruit people that do the fighting.  Then your task is to drag these people around letting them attack the enemy for you as they gain their own levels and lose their own health.  

The progress thread of the game is formatted in waves like any tower defense game.  Gold is dropped by your enemies to upgrade your fighters, unlock new fighters, upgrade your character's stats, and add features to the town and level.  You must make it to checkpoints to be able to start from them, which will prevent you from having to start the game from the very beginning for each run, similar to the way some roguelites work.  This design is where the game really hits its biggest problem.  It's set up in a way where you could, if it was at all possible, go through the entire game from the start, however you're easily beaten even before the first checkpoint in order to arbitrarily get the player to do upgrades.  This means that you're relegated to the same content repeatedly, not just to be able to get to a checkpoint, but to be able to gain enough gold to upgrade and move forward from that first it.  The game loses a lot of momentum very quickly with repetition, and upgrades rarely change the gameplay in any significant way.  I found myself burnt out on nearly every aspect within the first half hour.  What's worse is that they double down on that by featuring looped music and a lack of creativity in enemy design.  You end up living and dying by the upgrade system rather than player skill and that is a surefire way to make a game that slams the player with boredom.  

[h1]The dream lives on...[/h1]

I'm still going to be on the look out for developers that build good or even just average games on unique and fun concepts.  Bardbarian just isn't one of those.  Getting this game, regardless of it's low cost, isn't something I would recommend.  There are better games that cross over the tower defense and RPG genre out there, both new and old.  

If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/EndyoGaming#curation

author: {'steamid': '76561197982490998', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 487, 'playtime_forever': 2604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1530356362}
review:
Mon tower défense préféré!
Avec des graphismes typés cartoon comme je les aime, une ambiance tournée vers l'humour, et un concept unique... c'est une référence. 
Avec un nom pareil... On joue un barde barbare? et bah non, on a un bardrocker ou un barbarocker. On doit défendre la ville en se déplaçant et pas uniquement en posant des unités comme dans un TD traditionnel.
La bande sonore est enivrante et on se laisse porter. 
La progression va permettre des améliorations en tous genres: unités, ville, et perso.

Il y a cependant quelques petits soucis de traduction du jeu, mais a vrai dire, je m'en fiche. C'est juste bizarre de voir un texte en français, puis le suivant en anglais.
D'habitude je rale sur le prix, mais à 8€, je trouve que ça passe. Même si 5€ serait plus correct. Et en promo, je crois qu'il est à 3€. A ne pas rater donc (enfin, si vous aimez les TD)!

author: {'steamid': '76561198095392075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1503865201}
review:
Un gioco leggero, per passare il tempo, lungo quanto basta per finirlo al 100% prima che annoi.
La colonna sonora è interessante e prende molto, tuttavia dopo qualche ora diventa effettivamente parecchio ripetitiva.
E' molto semplice, si prendono 3 tipi di unità, ognuna ha un costo, un punteggio di vita e un punteggio di attacco. Puoi evocarne un tot in campo contemporaneamente e combattono al fianco del bardo, ad una distanza impostata dai potenziamenti che hai acquistato. Ondate di nemici, ha un che di tower defence ma, rispetto a molti altri che ho provato, parecchia più dinamicità.

+++PRO+++
+Comandi molto semplici, intuitivo.
+Frenetico ma non impossibile, ci sono parecchi elementi a schermo ma non eccessivi, anche in modalità difficile.
+I minigiochi aiutano a spezzare dalla modalità normale permettendo comunque di ottenere soldi per i potenziamenti
+Gli easter egg sono carini, strizzano l'occhio ma non sono in quantità spropositata in ogni dove
+Il gioco riesce a prendersi in giro (un barbaro bardo che suona un liuto per combattere orde di nemici?) senza però scadere nel ridicolo, anzi, fa sorridere.


---CONTRO---
-Bellissima colonna sonora, certo, ma se avessero messo una soundtrack un po' diversa ogni 5 orde invece che cambiarla solo durante i boss... l'avrei preferito.
-Non aspettatevi chissà che longevità. Una volta finito è finito, puoi migliorare il punteggio, ma una volta sbloccati tutti i potenziamenti (una cosa che si fa tranquillamente in 4-5 ore di gioco) è finito.
-La differenza tra modalità normale e difficile è ben poco tangibile

review: Super fun and addicting game with some replay value!  the main story being 20 levels where you unlock all of the soldiers to help beat the game and move onto day two, which is the same 20 levels only harder.  other 2 game modes are survival and escape, escape is a side scroller where you have to avoid a big wall that constantly chases you while weaving through enemies attacking while you are only 1 hit from death, and survival being a small map where enemies constantly spawn with a kicker being your soldiers randomly spawn as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094257044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1669404468}
review:
Comprei só pq estava na promoção, e me surpreendi positivamente!  É muito divertido, bem feito, engraçado e ao mesmo tempo desafiador.  Você controla um "Bardo do Metal", que toca guitarra e evoca arqueiros, magos, ninjas, etc, para lutarem por ele, que fica lá de boa tocando sua guitarrinha. Há buffs que ele também pode "tocar", fora o Especial. Ao matar inimigos eles podem dropar notinhas musicais, que vão se acumulando para que vc continue evocado/buffando, e cada um custa um X de notinhas musicais. Os mobs também dropam gold, que você vai juntando para aprimorar tanto os seus guerreiros, como a saúde do próprio Bardo, aspectos da "cidade", aumentar o número de carinhas que vc pode evocar, e etc. Conforme os inimigos acertam Bardo ele vai ficando machucado e perdendo vida, mas há uma BANQUINHA DE BACON (!!!!!!!) que regenera sua vida de tempo em tempo. Tem uma vasta variedade de monstros inimigos, fora os Chefes, cada um com sua difiiculdade... Quanto mais longe vc for, mais dificeis eles vão ficando. 
Há também dois modos a parte do jogo em si, que também são divertidos. 
Eu comprei em promoção, mas o preço integral dele é bem barato tbm... VALE MTO A PENA!

author: {'steamid': '76561198142296127', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1455640060}
review: Another child died today Garfield. He was terrified. In that moment I wished I could merge with his fear and slip into a saccharine foreverscream. But this is my duty Garfield, have you stopped eating my lasagna? Have you ever looked in that pan? When was the last time you tasted what you were chewing? You shuffling, bumbling, crusty, dumb♥♥♥♥ cat Garfield. If I pelted you with rocks who would hear the dumb screams? If I set myself on fire and smothered you who would die first? You're a tumor Garfield, but God made cancer, just like he made lasagna, except I made the lasagna. Does that make me more than a man? They call you a "bad cat" but they will never drink from the fat and rotten juices, they are unfit to be in the kingdom of Heaven and Hell Garfield. You are cut from the nape of the Earth, you little bitty cat. Don't kick Odie off the table!! Gaaarfiiieeeeld!!!! You stumble home drunk and your bits are all cut away. Did you let someone get to them? Did you snip them off yourself? You won't tell me. Instead you sit in front of the telly, sagging and staring at a sitcom. Your bits are still bleeding. Chunks soak into the upholstery. You'll be fine tomorrow Garfield You live here, Garfield. You are in between the walls and the beams but you live here. I breathe you in sometimes. It makes me remember innocence. I scream and shake outside of the shower. I try to step in but I slip on a wacky tie. I catch a glimpse of you on the way down just outside of the door frame. Your smile all pus and burn scars. Whose face will it be tomorrow? Garfield, I am your keeper. I just can't seem to get a date! A thousand shifting fever dreams couldn't molest my love for you, Garfield. It runs through the wires and the cogs and the paper cuts and the plushies. It died twenty years ago. It's pumped up again from a black river bottom and vomited onto naked little bodies. Can I remove myself from its fate? They pick at you like a great big feast. Garfield, your bulbous thoughts were always clear. I just didn't want to hear. But now it doesn't matter. Now you will see tomorrow. A thousand million living things melted for you. A hundred thousand writhing tongues coming from you. It's a wonderful world and this is all that there is. Tell me you're happy, you fatty cat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062935682', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1708833616}
review:
tl;dr I find this game not great but still decent, and actually with quite a high skill ceiling that other reviewers calling this a boring grindfest might not have discovered.

Longer version: 
Having read other reviews, I started playing this game with the expectation of mucking around casually for awhile and then stopping when it gets too grindy.

However, what I found was a rather fun and challenging game with an unexpected amount of strategical and tactical depth. Take, for instance, a common complaint that the party's hitbox is too large to apply common bullet hell techniques. However, notice that whenever you about-face the Bardbarian, his entire party maintains formation by going *through* him. When that happens, the party's hitbox shrinks significantly. It's still not a single point like in other bullet hell games, but by using this technique appropriately, you can actually dodge a *lot* of stuff.

Applying this and other techniques, and abusing various enemy behaviours and unit compositions, I did not have to grind much to beat the vanilla game, though I did have to grind what I felt was an acceptable amount. And whenever I died, I did not feel like it was due to not having grinded enough, but that it was due to a lack of skill or moment of carelessness which I then wanted to immediately improve upon.

That being said, I do feel that the movement is still rather clunky, the enemies and units are not wholly satisfying, and the game on the whole is a little lackluster, which is why I think that this is merely a decent game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098455928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1495661578}
review:
Pretty fun tower defense game with RPG elements. Took me over 11 hours to get all achievements as I played both normal and insane modes -- I suggest just doing insane mode as soon as you can since two of the achievements require you to complete it. The enemies are a little more difficult in insane mode, but you get gold much faster, allowing you to upgrade faster, so it balances out.

The good:
++ Wide range of units and enemy types give different ways to play and cause you to come up with different strategies.
++ The upgrade system for your units, the town, and perks for your hero are interesting and give some customization (until you just upgrade everything to max).
++ The artwork and unit designs are visually appealing.
++ A couple perks help you speed up how quickly you gain gold in story mode, which is helpful.
++ The music is good but gets repetitive after a while.
++ Full controller support.

The bad:
-- Becomes monotonous after a while. It really turns into a grind to get more gold to upgrade perks and units. To get the most gold, you have to beat the bosses, meaning you have to just replay from the beginning over and over. By the time you have a bunch of upgrades, this grind becomes ridiculously easy at the beginning levels and just a bullet hell at the end. Repeat until you get all achievements.
-- Survival and Escape game modes give different ways of playing the game but are pretty much only used to get an achievement for each as they're not an efficient way to earn gold. Plus, they're endless, so the only goal is to beat your best score or get on the leaderboard -- not a real reason to keep playing them.

If you play this game more casually, playing just a little at a time to seemingly reduce the grind, you'd probably get more out of it. Overall, I'd rate it 6/10, OK. Might want to wait for it to go on sale before you buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120567690', 'num_games_owned': 939, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1493576676}
review:
Bardbarian is a flash based twin (actually single) stick shooter game, where the player doesn't have to shoot (because our party members do that automatically), just avoid the projectiles of the enemies and protect a crystal at the centre of the town. The game deploys various units we can use to kill the attackers and we can also use diverse upgrades to increase our chances for success. There's a main storyline and 2 alternative game modes.

One day, Brad, a retired barbarian decides to change profession and modifies his waraxe into a lute, therefore he becomes the Bardbarian. Of course the town he lives in happens to be in danger, so he must put his new skills into good use, by playing all kinds of tunes to summon allies and boost their abilities. Quite strange, huh? It reflects the general mood of the whole game and it does manage to be amusing.

The gameplay is simple, but enjoyable nevertheless: we have to kill increasing waves of monsters who swarm towards us from right to left and defend the crystal in the heart of our town from them. Since Brad is completely defenseless (maybe turning his waraxe into a lute wasn't exactly the brightest idea), we have to summon a group of units, who will be following us and let them do the killing. This will cost us music notes (displayed with blue numbers in the top-right corner of the screen) which is automatically generated as Brad plays his lute (it regenerates faster if we stand still). This will be our most important factor as it allows us to summon units and to play special boosting songs, that can increase our team's damage, defence, speed and a special one as well (which requires 5 kills to fill up), that can stun our enemies for a short while while also destroying their projectiles.
Just left to our music notes lies a yellow number showing the amount of gold we have, which we can pick up after killing enemies. With gold we can't do anything during the gameplay, but after restarting, we can purchase several important upgrades, that will be the key to our victory. Most importantly we can unlock new, more powerful units, increase the maximum number of our followers and their permanent level (they can also gain levels during gameplay, but they'll lose it once they die) and we can also get more hit points for Brad, increase speed, music note regeneration, moreover the defense of the town can be improved by purchasing guard towers, reinforce the crystal and so on. The first thing we should buy however is an upgrade that doubles the amount of all the gold we find :)
My favourite was a guy only labeled as the Town Drunk, who runs vertically between the inn and the bottom of the screen with a mug of beer in his hand, puking occasionly, creating puddles of green goo which can slow down and weaken enemies that step into them...

There's a wide variety of units at our disposal, but we can have only 3 types of them at a time in our party (we can summon multiple ones from the same type) and it would be logical to pick the most expensive ones. That's not the case however and I found some of them much more effective than the others, but of course this depends on one's playstyle too. The best combination in my opinion is a party composed of ninjas (excellent firing speed and damage), wizards (not the black, but the blue ones with lightning bolts that can pass through enemies and have knockback effect) and a shaman (whose spear can curse, slow down and summon totems on the corpses of fallen enemies). These guys all have great firing range as well, which is very important as we want to keep the distance from our foes, since going closer to them increases the chance of getting hit and relatively good damage too. It should also be noted that they can be unlocked quite early (except for maybe the shaman). The extra units (imported from other games) like Octodad, may seem funny, but their usefulness is minimal.
Enemy units are all a bit similar (they have different velocity shots) but that's OK, they provide a fair challenge (or can be almost impossible to overcome if you have a wrong set of party members) and they are determined to kill either Brad or the town crystal. There are four bosses, one at the end of each episode who are naturally harder to kill.

The other 2 game modes are 'survival', in which the longer we stay alive against the endlessly spawning foes the more scores we get and 'escape', where we must run from a horde of enemies and dodge obstacles. These game modes provide easy way to get money for the main story, but there are also achievements related to them. I found the escape mode more effective to collect large amounts of money, but it's only true after having reached a certain length, because the amount of gold piles increase drastically as we progress after that.
Having said that most people who criticize the game have problems with acquiring gold and the fact that grinding is required. By purchasing only the necessary upgrades (the gold doubling upgrade, the gold collecting raccoon, the 3 types of units I mentioned) it can be reduced to a minimal amount and the main story can still be finished even on insane difficulty.

Controls are fine, but the use of a controller is heavily advised. This is one of those games which are quite a bit easier using a controller, so do yourself a favour by playing it with one.

The graphics is what one could expect from a flash based game: very simple and cartoonish looking (which I don't like), but the animations are funny and it doesn't really need more. The music changes as Brad plays his different songs but still way too simplistic and can get on one's nerves, the same goes for the sound effects.

Bardbarian is an absolutely fun little casual game that can be entertaining for anyone (provided they have a controller) longing for a few hours of fun and monster killing with alternative game modes.

PROS
+ simple yet entertaining gameplay
+ plenty of units and upgrades to choose from
+ 2 alternative game modes beside the main story

CONS
- a bit of a grinding is required to unlock the desired upgrades
- music is annoying 

RATING
7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1492296174}
review:
It helps for a game to have a clever hook, but it needs more than just that. Doing something outside the norm is great as long as that's expanded into a full game and not left to prop the whole thing up. Bardbarian has a cute premise but really doesn't go much further than that, seemingly expecting the one joke it's built around and a few cameos from other indie games to carry its terribly thin gameplay. That works for an hour or so, and then it just becomes a grinding slog without a punchline.

Bardbarian is the tale of Brad, mighty barbarian and defender of some dinky village with a giant, important, and otherwise unprotected crystal at its center. On this particular day Brad doesn't feel like vanquishing evil, instead opting to fashion a guitar out of an old battleaxe and jam out. Luckily for him, the villagers, and you, this inspires all manner of mercenaries to come to his aid, shredding monsters as he shreds and drawing power from his power chords.

In other words, you control Brad but you never attack on your own. You can call in one of three chosen units when you have enough chords (generated passively) which will follow you around and attack things within their range. At first you can only call three helpers at a time but through the game's gold-powered upgrade system you can raise that limit, as well as upgrade each mercenary. Brad can also spend chords to buff his team in various ways, and stun enemies when he reaches certain killstreaks.

Monsters come from three lanes on the right and trundle towards your crystal on the left, and if either that or Brad is destroyed, game over. Your minions also have health, so you'll need to weave your whole formation through the lazy projectiles your foes will lob. The game is broken into four chapters of five lengthy waves each, with a boss on the fifth wave. Everything drops gold for you to buy upgrades with between runs; once you start playing you're locked into what you have until you win or die.

This is where the game starts to wear thin, because death is going to be stopping you pretty regularly. There's a significant jump in difficulty between chapters, mainly because of enemies getting huge health and damage boosts. Little critters you could kill in 3 arrows suddenly take 12. It feels like the power curve of a mobile game, forcing you to grind on your current level before unlocking enough upgrades to stand a chance at the next. That's exactly what I did, too, playing chapter 1 until I had the archer units fully upgraded, along with a larger squad size and higher base levels and other stuff. Chapter 2 was still a challenge but I pulled it off, and then Chapter 3 immediately kicked me in the balls until I died.

Ultimately the upgrade system is going to be your main focus, and it isn't even that interesting to begin with. Unit upgrades just make them generally beefier but the early units don't hold a candle to the later ones you unlock, so you can waste gold on guys that can't carry you to the finish line. There's a 2x drops unlock that's basically mandatory but terribly expensive, and the squad size upgrade is obviously the most important but scales ludicrously in cost. It's going to take a lot of grinding the same waves over and over, which will exacerbate how slow and long they tend to be, and how little you actually need to do besides dodging bullets.

Even the actual combat is underwhelming, with slow projectiles and weak sound effects for all of them. You get virtually no feedback on damage, either, with a hit doing a sliver of health and a hit one-shotting you looking and sounding exactly the same. There's very little variety in enemy behavior as well, and that extends even to the bosses. And forget about the survival and escape modes, because they dumb down the gameplay even further. Like I said, it's a cute concept to hang a game on but Bardbarian is paper-thin, offering little in the way of content or challenge to keep you rocking along.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

review: Grindfest. You cannot progress in the game without having to repeat previous levels over and over and over again in order to be able to afford the upgrades you need. author: {'steamid': '76561198147485569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1491505816}
review:
[b][h1]Bardbarian[/h1][/b]

Estimated gameplay hours: 6-7-10.

[b][u]Game Genre:[/u][/b] 2D Mixed Strategy-Tower Def with RPG elements.
This game may look like one of those cheap internet / app games but it is very enjoyable to play.

[b][u]Gameplay:[/u][/b] Your goal is to defend the town by killing the enemies round after round, but what makes it good is the RPG aspect.
You have 20 rounds, 4 bosses & more than 15 units & hero/town upgrades that would help you sucessfully survive each round.

If you're not getting bored from random games very fast and have an open mind for this type of game, you will find it fun to play therefore, I recommend it.

[b]Overall Score: 8/10[/b]

[b]*Game Tips*[/b]
[i]-- Units --[/i] I used Archer & Mage at lower rounds and few Wizards + 2 Tank & 1 Shaman at higher rounds, it works well.
(Necromancer at mid rounds is also recommended).
[i]-- Hero Skills --[/i] 'Golden Axe' first, Damage,Speed,Party upgrade(more units) & Note Regeneration+Distance between units.
[i]-- Town Upgrades -- [/i] 'Friends', Pet skill is a must, Magic castle (for magic units XP Level) & 'Town Drunk' is also nice.

[i]* Skip it.[/i]
[i]** Not Recommended.[/i]
[h1][i][b]*** Give It A Try.[/b][/i][/h1]
[h1][i][b]**** Recommended On Sale.[/b][/i][/h1]
[i]****** Recommended On Full Price.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041150422', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1488851071}
review: Unit upgrades affect your progress in the game.   Might be fun for a challenge to try and run through it using a new game save with as much stuff maxed out before starting day 1 since unlocked units don't show up between waves again after you have unlocked them.  Ignore the developer's description, whatever nonsense that is.  Stop enemies from reaching the left side via controlling a large hitbox of grouped units.  Music would be good if there was more than one song the entire game.  Beat it using necromancer to provide a wall, rune knight for attack, and shaman to slow mobs down.  Sadly, more necros don't result in more zombies and you're limited to six.  The final boss fight was a little unintuitiive at first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113758912', 'num_games_owned': 1738, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1486653067}
{'steamid': '76561197973785927', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1485900243}
review:
I have to say, I had a blast with this game.  It’s essentially a type of DOTA/tower defense game.  Your role is to summon and buff an NPC party that follows you automatically performs its roll.  Attackers target and attack enemies in range, healers heal when you stop walking, defenders deflect ranged enemy attacks when they are struck and so on.  You earn gold as you play which you spend after you die to improve the town, units, buffs and other aspects of the game.  The music is pretty great too, it was stuck in my head for days.  There are 3 gameplay modes, which lets you switch things up a bit, as well as a harder dificulty to select when you create a new game file.

My list of complaints is pretty short.  Some of the units felt pretty underwhelming, and if you pick a good group you are essentially unbeatable, which can hurt replayability.  Since you only get one town and never go anywhere else there isn’t much opportunity for the game to present situations where using specific units or combinations is very impactful.  There isn’t much variety of enemies, which isn’t a big deal, but I think is worth noting.

I would love to see more locations added in an update, but as is it is still a great little game I would recommend picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032794955', 'num_games_owned': 3659, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1479139728}
review:
移动塔防类游戏，出乎意料地好玩，整个流程就是刷钱-解锁新人物-升级角色，还有生存模式和跑酷模式选择，轻松休闲，掌握套路后无难度。

快速流程：开档直接INSANE模式，战斗中只召唤弓箭手，一直刷故事模式，能打多远打多远，中途升级弓箭手到3-4级之后就不要花钱了，一直存钱到5000块，解锁双倍金币技能（Golden Axe-Flute），然后再打一点钱解锁Town Pet并升到2级，这个时候打钱就比较快了，再解锁Party On、Body Spray和Song of Attack这三个技能并升到3级左右，此时打通早晨毫无压力。一直往前面推，直到解锁忍者，这个时候把所有钱全部用来升级忍者到满星，钱不够就一直从第一关开始打，光是打通早晨就有1W8的钱。前面说的三个技能也升满，然后全程7忍者打怪。打完倒数第三关解锁风暴骑士（Storm Knight）后把全部钱用来升级这个英雄到满星，此时队伍就可以换成7个骑士了，基本上是全程碾压INSANE难度。如果想拿100%完成度的成就的话，打通故事模式后开启day 2，只刷前三波，刷一次大概能有8W左右的钱，刷几把下来足够你升级所有英雄和技能到满星了。

全成就比较容易，大概6小时左右拿到（我开始还傻乎乎地浪费时间去打普通难度，完全没有必要）。总体上来说是一个不错的休闲类游戏，值得一玩。

author: {'steamid': '76561198000926595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1484931353}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008870686', 'num_games_owned': 1268, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1483759924}
review:
Hey this is a fun game.  You control a bard who has a group of warriors wizards etc. that you can lead into battle to fight off waves of enemies.  The waves are like what you'd find in a tower defense game, and you pick and choose your crew that follow you around on the battlefield, attacking enemies that are near.  The strategy comes in who you add to your party, and taking money earned in rounds to buy upgrades to you, your recruits and the town you are defending.

Its a good simple game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009528477', 'num_games_owned': 1986, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1484668534}
review:
If you enjoy a good (?) grindfest just to play a tower defense game, in which your only task is to run around dodging bullets, then this is what you want to buy.
To me it felt more like a chore. There is no real motivation, your whole aspiration is basically trying to amass enough gold to buy all the upgrades and then breeze through the game. Problem is, that you don't really have to invest much effort gameplay wise and even if you do, the rewards are just more gold and some unlockable characters, which might or might not have a use to your playing style and whose upgrades you have to pay for with that good old gold again. The whole "grind gold" aspect really shows that this was/is a mobile game and the model might work there with their f2p games, but on a PC game I expect a bit more meat on the bone.

Other than that it can be an alright 10 minute time waster but nothing you'd wanna play for a longer time. You're basically that barbarian guy, who's tired of grinding for xp so he decided to now grind for gold, which shows us why barbarians have such a low intelligence stat in every rpg ever. To fulfill that tedious task, you're equipped with an axe that is used as a guitar and you're able to summon some followers (who actually do the fighting for you and follow you in a weird snake-like fashion) and to play three different buffs (speed, dmg, def). Your job is to protect the core from baddies, there's a bossfight every 5 or so stages (20 stages in total iirc) and that's that. You are also only able to upgrade your things once you die, so be prepared to start over quite a few times. Sounds thrilling ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198055977195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1484526067}
review:
Bardbarian
About The Game: Bardbarian is a mix between a side scroller hack n'slash, a bullet hell, and a tower defence game. You play as Brad the barbarian, turned bard. It is still your job to defend the town from goblin and demon hordes. This time you let your groupies do all the hard work as you riff and jam about the place. Chose 3 from up to 18 different groupies, along with 16 upgrades between you and the town. After death you get your collected gold to make upgrades, and then try again to beat your record.

Pantsu's Rating (out of 5)
Graphics: 3.5 Nothing epic but still clean and not really glitchy. Although i find monsters hiding under the bottom HUD.
Playability: 4 WSDA movement with changeable hotkeys for summons and solos make the controls enjoyable.
Fun: 3.5 This game is pretty fun but after a while it gets tedious keeping your groupies from eating bullets.
Sound: 4 Metal jams and solo riffs entertain the ears. The background music is upbeat and keeps the action flowing.
Replay Value: 3 There are extra modes including an insane mode, Halloween mode, survival mode, and an escape mode. As for the main game, once you fully upgrade everything there isn't much left to do.
Final Score: 3.5
Final Thought: At $7.99 it is worth waiting for a sale but on a good note, it is offered in a bundle with another Treefortress game, Jump Jet Rex, and soundtrack for $14.99.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022319291', 'num_games_owned': 4885, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1483486868}
review: Что будет, если смешать Plants vs. Zombies, Tower Defens и Zombie Tycoon. Ответ прост. Bardbarian на мой взгляд один из лучших андроидовских портов для PC. Нам предстоит играть за барда, который сам никого не атакует, зато способен призвать на подмогу внушительное число соратников, у которых есть свои плюсы и минусы. Отсюда и различные тактики прохождения игры. Также есть апгрейды как для самого барда, так и для его юнитов и замка. Игра проходится буквально на одном дыхании. По скидке стоит брать однозначно.

review:
Divertido, original, con buena música y diferentes personajes desbloqueables!! (MeatBoy&Isaac, Octodad, Megaman?)

Diferentes modos de juego. Campaña, Supervivencia y 'Carrera'. Mas otro desbloqueable al acabar el modo Campaña.

Tendremos que invocar a nuestros subditos con acordes y cuando creamos necesario también usar 'power-ups' para deshacernos de las oleadas.Evitando asi que destruyan nuestro 'Nucleo'. Nosotros NO dispararemos, lo harán los subditos que elijamos o invoquemos. Nos dedicaremos a esquivar, tocar nuestra hacha-guitarra. Elegir los momentos mas oportunos para darnos potencia extra sera la clave!!! 

Just ROCK!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967626206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1481782368}
review:
I just can't recommend this game, even though that puts me in a small minority. I play a lot of casual, quick games. They key thing is they need to entertain me quickly, easily and just have short bursts of fun. 

I started this game, and realised I was just... well... bored...

Take games like Guild of Dungeoneering, The Binding of Isaac. Diehard Dungeon, One Finger Death Punch or a lot of other awesome casual games. They are fun, quickly. 

This honestly wasn't. I was just running around dodging while my summons fire. If I compare it to The Binding of Isaac, which is also broadly about running around dodging and shooting, this just isn't in the same league. I know they are different, but ultimately, one is fun, the other just isn't. Sorry, but casual shouldn't equal mundane. The team have tried. And it's a polished game (other than sloppy text not lining up with the dialogue boxes). But it's just plain boring unfortunately :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198005741042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1399837394}
review:
Croisement entre tower défense, beat'em all tellement les "balles" fusent, et pseudo-RPG avec progression des unités, du village et du héros, Bardbarian est rafraîchissant et tout en français. Seul défaut, avec une seule mélodie répétée à l'infini, Assurancetourix n'a rien à craindre. Brad, lui aussi on finit par le bailloner. Non, franchement, là, les développeurs auraient pu nous proposer quelques pistes endiablées supplémentaires.  

  [url=http://www.rpgjeuxvideo.com/bardbarian-a127285054] Le test complet [/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561197972433429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1539992740}
review: A fun casual game; I'd say it's worth the ticket price if you pick it up on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048865581', 'num_games_owned': 2546, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1479051421}
review:
Bardbarian is a cute casual wave survival game.

The story doesn't exist, so check that off.
The graphics look cartoony and nice. It's pleasing to the eye for sure. 
It runs well. The achievements are easy to get and the soundtrack is really good. After writing this review, I'll find a way to get it. 
You can play the game on either normal or hardcore, but all achievement hunters should want to play on hardcore. 
After that you have the main survival mode, runner mode and a Day 2 mode that unlocks after the game's been beaten. It's all good and fun. It works and that's what matters.

Overall, I'd recommend this game if you want a casual experience.
5/10

(All games start off at a 5/10 and the grade raises and lowers for every pro and con present)

author: {'steamid': '76561197992208010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1478257447}
review:
I have played a significant amount of this game. It's good. Much better than the closest title I can think of in terms of mood and gameplay, that being plants vs zombies - and unlike that title, it represents a challenge.
The ending is a little weak, you'd think they'd put in at least as much effort as they put into the intro (which wasn't much).
But it's an enjoyable game.

Think tower defense meets bullet hell meets Dungeon Siege, and you're kind of close. Whimsical.
Only beef is with the difficulty level, which curves rather drastically.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997355440', 'num_games_owned': 3002, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1476795860}
review:
En general, un juego pequeño muy bien hecho. Por momentos, me recuerda al Plants vs. Zombies original, en el sentido de que está diseñado para ser compacto y elegante, sin profundidad artificial de montones de opciones o actualizaciones de funcionalidad ininteligible y con el suficiente sentido del humor para que, ahí donde pueda faltar motivación para continuar por la prácticamente nula historia o la profundidad limitada, alcance para volver a intentarlo. La progresión es constante y regularmente cualquier ronda alcanza para adquirir una mejora más, que además, al estar limitadas a cinco o tres en cada apartado, la diferencia entre niveles es apreciable. No como, digamos, en esos juegos donde hay 10 o 20 niveles y la diferencia entre el nivel 14 y el 15 es imperceptible.

Como puntos negativos, aunque estas son más obsesiones mías: no puede bajarse el volumen de la música. Apagada o prendida, solamente. Y aborrezco cuando los personajes de un juego son conscientes de estar en un juego y digan cosas como «cansado de reunir XP, se fue a su casa» y similares. Cosa más triste no hay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138440173', 'num_games_owned': 1124, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1472042974}
review:
[h1][b]Bardbarian ist ein RPG Tower-Defense von TreeFortress Games[/b][/h1]

In Bardbarian spielt der Spieler einen barbarischen Barden, der sein Dorf mit Hilfe seiner zauberhaften Metalkräfte beschützt.

[h1]Hauptmenü:[/h1]

Im Hauptmenü wird der Spieler vom blonden Barden, einigen seiner Kumpane und ein paar fiesen Gegnern begrüßt.
Dieses Hauptmenü kann in zwei verschiedenen Modi ausgeführt werden. Normal und Halloween.

Das Hauptmenü ist übersichtlich, es gibt vier wählbare Reiter: Settings, Play, Credits, Exit.

Das Hauptmenü ist interaktiv, wenn die Maus sich bewegt, bewegt sich auch der Hintergrund. Es gibt sogar etwas zu entdecken, dies sollte der Spieler jedoch selbst herausfinden.


[h1]Spielmodi:[/h1]

Es gibt 2 Hauptmodi: [b]Normal[/b] und [b]Nightmare[/b], diese unterscheiden sich in ihrer Schwierigkeit.
In diesen Hauptmodi beschützt der Spieler sein Dorf, wertet dieses auf und kauft nützliche Dinge.
Es gibt 20 Wellen, alle fünf Wellen erscheinen ein oder mehrere Bossgegner.


In diesen Spielmodi befinden sich noch Minispiele.

[b]"Unendlich":[/b] Hier läuft der Spieler durch einen endlosen Level und versucht allem Unangenehmen auszuweichen.

[b]"Überleben":[/b] Der Spieler ist in einem Level mit begrenztem Platz und versucht, so lange wie möglich, zu überleben. Es spawnen immer mehr Gegner. Manchmal spawnen auch Kumpane, Bacon (heilt 25% leben) und Noten (nötig, um Zauber zu wirken) mit deren Hilfe das Überleben gesichert werden soll.

[b]"Day 2":[/b] Day 2 ist ein freischaltbarer Modus, in welchem die Wellen vom Hauptspiel weitergehen.


[h1]Schwierigkeit:[/h1]

Die Schwierigkeit des Spiels variiert nur leicht zwischen "Normal" und "Nightmare", ausschlaggebend ist hier eher, wie weit man im Spiel fortgeschritten ist und wie viele Kumpane man bereits freigeschalten hat.


[h1]Grafik:[/h1]

Bardbarian hat eine lustige Comic-Grafik, welche zum Spiel passt und die Atmosphäre unterstützt.


[h1]Musik:[/h1]

In Bardbarian spielt im Hintergrund ausschließlich Alternative Rock und Metal, was zu unserem harten Barden sehr gut passt.
Die wenigen Musikstücke sind sehr gut gemacht und für jeden Metal-Fan ein Ohrenschmaus.


[h1]Spielspaß:[/h1]

Bardbarian macht nicht nur zwischendurch Mal kurz Spaß, es ist auch für längere Spielsessions geeignet und macht sogar ein wenig süchtig, wenn man, wie ich, immer in der letzten Welle abkratzt *hust*.


[h1]Spielzeit:[/h1]

Persönlich habe ich, zum Zeitpunkt dieses Reviews, 10,7 Stunden gebraucht, um alle Errungenschaften zu erhalten. Ein durchschnittlicher Spieler dürfte zwischen 5 und 7 Stunden brauchen. 
Dadurch hält sich die Spielzeit in Grenzen.

[h1]Preis/Leistung:[/h1]

8€ sind für die meisten Tower-Defense Spiele eine Stangen Geld. Aber durch die große Menge an Content, Spielspaß und verdammt gut gemachte Grafik und Musik, lohnt es sich, Bardbarian zu kaufen.


[h1] Errungenschaften:[/h1]

Es gibt 22 Errungenschaften, von denen die meisten innerhalb kürzester Zeit erreicht werden können, die letzten Errungenschaften können, wenn man so blöd ist, wie ich, einige Zeit auf sich warten. Dafür kann man dann länger spielen.


[h1]Hauptmenü: 9/10[/h1]
[h1]Spielmodi: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Schwierigkeit: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Grafik: 8/10[/h1]
[h1]Musik: 8/10[/h1]
[h1]Spielspaß: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Spielzeit: 6/10[/h1]
[h1]Preis/Leistung: 9/10[/h1]

[h1][b]Gesamtpunktzahl: 8/10[/b][/h1]

[b]Wenn dir dieses Review gefallen hat, dann sieh dir doch die andere Reviews unserer Kuratorengruppe an![/b]
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/-German_Gamer_Community-

[b]Omakoma over and out![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198126147324', 'num_games_owned': 1041, 'num_reviews': 529, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1460479960}
review: Sympatyczna. Mieszanka shootera, tower defense z naciskiem na zręczność w klimatach fantasy. Całkiem niezła gra. 3 Tryby rozgrywki: Obrona miasteczka, przed hordami wrogów; Jak najdłuższe przeżycie na małej przestrzeni wśród rosnącej liczby coraz to potężniejszych wrogów oraz ucieczka przed mrokiem, czyli omijanie przeszkód na drodze w ciągłym ruchu. Z czasem jednak trochę nudzi, ale dla osób, które nastawione są na zręcznościowe wyzwania może przypaść do gustu 6/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037854231', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1659140467}
review:
Apesar de parecer simples como a maioria de jogos do estilo "Tower Defense", Bardbarian tem seu diferencial.

- É necessário ter uma boa mobilidade para desviar das habilidades inimigas e tbm controlar o range de atk e habilidades de sua party, característica pouco encontrada em "TDs" e mais em jogos Arcade.
-Vc não ataca, apenas sua party (exceto 1 healer e 1 tank que reflete projéteis), mas usuflúi de 4 "Solos"(buffs) com efeitos caracteríscos de acordo com a necessidade, e summona até 4 diferentes unidades pra te ajudar (somando até 9 simultâneas).
-Existem inúmeras combinações de party possibilitando várias estratégias diferentes, o que deixa o jogo menos enjoativo e mais desafiador.
-Vc pode upar sua vila (base), aumentando a vida do "Nexus"(q vc deve proteger), 2 torres auxiliares próximas do "Nexus", pode tbm upar as lojas e NPCs de sua vila pra te ajudarem com comida (cura), dinheiro e CC (slow). 
-Pode aprimorar seu personagem (Vida, mobilidade, ganho de gold, buffs, distanciamento da party, quantidade máxima da party até 9, etc.)
-Pode desbloquear e aprimorar cada personagem da sua party, cada um com suas características e habilidades.
-Não é um jogo longo, dá pra zerar sem antes enjoar, tanto que vc vai querer fazer as conquistas conforme vai evoluindo.
-Depois de matar os 4 chefes das 20 fases é liberado lvls 21+ os quais acredito eu que não tenha fim, pois são extremamente difíceis conforme vai passando de fase, ainda mais se for jogar no modo insano.
-Tem tbm o modo Survival e Escape.
-Trilha sonora empolgante que deixa a jogatina mais frenética e não te deixa perder o ritmo.

Em promoção vale a pena comprar o jogo, pois é um ótimo passatempo pra qdo quer jogar algo diferente pra distrair a cabeça e se divertir. Minha filha adorou me ver jogando! Rsrsrsrsrsrsrsrs

Eu particulamente recomendo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010267364', 'num_games_owned': 1213, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1468378909}
review:
Repetition in video games can be draining sometimes. There's only so many times you can jump on things, slash them, shoot them, right? And if that's the case for you the player, what must it be like for the characters actually doing the work? Bardbarian's a game that explores that a bit.

You play as Brad, a barbarian mercenary working to defend a nameless town and its giant magic crystal, which does...probably something important, since every monster in the area wants it smashed, although they never get around to saying what. Trouble is, Brad is having a bit of a mid-life crisis: surely there must be more to life than constant killing? The answer to that he finds is embracing his artistic side in the form of music, and helping other people kill things!

Bardbarian takes place in the town for the whole of the game, as twenty waves assault the crystal over the course of a single day. These make up four sections, with five levels each and a boss at the end. To combat them, Brad has to jam on his guitar and summon allies from out of the local barracks and wizard college; they move in to close formation around him, not unlike Tiny Guardians. This game is action-based, however, and you'll be moving back and forth to let your allies shoot down monsters with either the arrow keys, WADS, the mouse or a controller. You start off with a simple archer-wizard-fighter combo, but as you unlock units by passing waves you'll find more interesting ones, like a necromancer who curses enemies, and resurrects them as a zombie minion if they're killed under the effects of it. There are also some indie cameos from Octodad, a Super Meat Boy/Isaac tag team, and Shellrazer, who's from a mobile tower defense that isn't on Steam.

If twenty waves sounds a bit short to you, well, it kind of is. The length mostly comes from you kind of having to go back and upgrade your allies, Brad himself, and the town with the gold you get from killing enemies; even if you're very good at dodging they'll simply get too spongey. After every boss you'll have the option of starting at the next area whenever you do, so you won't have to start at the beginning every time. There are also upgrades to make gathering gold easier, such as the Pet, who will grab it from dead enemies so you don't have to.

Even with upgrades, though, the game can be quite tricky, and I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to people without experience in shooters. Most enemies have some sort of projectile attack, and it isn't long before it a minor bullet hell, with you weaving in and out to protect your squishier allies and Brad himself. You'll need to be proactive when dealing with enemies, too, as letting even a couple goblins get up to the crystal can lead to quite a bit of damage. Naturally, it's also a game over if you die yourself. And if you really want a challenge, there's an even harder difficulty you can pick right from the start.

It took me about nine hours to beat the game, although it might take a bit longer for someone not as good at action games. There are two optional modes in addition to it; a challenge mode where you try to survive against an endless horde of enemies, and a sort of runner minigame where you try to avoid obstacles. They can both give gold, but it still felt like the main campaign was the most efficient method of doing that, and it doesn't feel like they'd extend the playtime very much.

Bardbarian is definitely a good game if you can put up with some grinding, although I'm not certain I would buy it at full price. It's been on sale a bunch though, and can be found in one of the permanent bundles on BundleStars. It's a decent game with some charm for in-between larger ones, I'd say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083589505', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1468960384}
review:
Juego bastante divertido. No tiene muchas horas de juego, ni demasiada rejugabilidad en mi opinión, pero es un concepto divertido, y tiene una buena dificultad.

En resumen, te mueves por el mapa evitando que los enemigos lleguen al otro lado, como un Tower Defense. Sin embargo, tú no atacas. Invocas "seguidores" que se mueven contigo y atacan ellos automáticamente a los enemigos. Se trata de combinar los tipos de seguidores, y esquivar proyectiles para que los enemigos no los maten (ni te maten a ti).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035560545', 'num_games_owned': 3970, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1429425904}
review:
Supposedly the protagonist Brad got tired of the grind for XP and decided to retire to be a bard, but this game is still nothing but grind. 

Brad doesn’t directly attack enemies, but instead plays music to summon members of his party that are selected before the game starts. Half of the game is spending coins to upgrade all kinds of passives for the town, units and Brad himself, but the single upgrade paths are all standard. The player gets some sense of strategy by picking which units to include in their party, which is kind of like selecting what towers to build in a TD game, except being mobile takes away figuring out the puzzle of a good maze or what tower combinations are most efficient for an area. The other part of the game is spent as Brad running around while his party auto attacks enemies. After a while the game kind of feels like it plays itself for the most part.  It never seemed like I got better at fighting the same handful of enemies over and over again while listening to the same melody, in the same environment.
 
I bought in for the promise of more content, mainly co-op, and for the crossover characters. The crossover novelty was cool, but wore off, and the promised content has yet to come. Maybe I would have enjoyed it more with co-op, but overall it was a lukewarm experience. 

Bardbarian is functional and can be fun for a while, but it’s not really that engaging.

review: İyi düşünülmüş ve eğlenceli bir çerezlik Tower Defense oyunu. Oynanışı kolay ve eğlenceli. Grafikleri tatlış mı tatlış. author: {'steamid': '76561197987658658', 'num_games_owned': 1431, 'num_reviews': 341, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1590577838}
review:
https://youtu.be/VpGlwCFMqkE

Bardbarian, au delà de son nom rigolol est un Tower defense qui ne paye pas de mine mais qui est plutot sympathique. Vous dirigez un barbare qui doit défendre le centre ville d'attaques d'ennemis divers.
Ok, le barbare, il défonce tout et il coupe des têtes, c'est ça hein? 
En fait non, il a une guitarre qui lui sert à appeller des alliés qui vont s'occuper des ennemis à se place. Il peut également donner des buffs d'attaque, de défense et de vitesse mais il n'attaque pas.

Quelle est la particularité du jeu alors? Hé bien, comme le barbare n'attaque pas mais que les alliés suivent le barbare, il faut approcher le barbare suffisament près des ennemis pour que les alliés les défoncent. Le problème, c'est que, du coup, vous êtes maxi-exposé aux attaques adverses et susceptible de connaître un sort funeste. Toute la subtilité vient donc du fait de bien savoir bouger.

Les alliés, le héros et la ville peuvent être améliorés avec l'or récupéré.
Le contenu est plutot limité : 20 vagues, un mode infini et un mode fuite. Toutes les 5 vagues, vous avez un nouveau chapitre duquel vous pouvez démarer. Les vagues sont cependant difficiles et le défi de faire les 20 vagues d'une traite promet de ne pas être aisé.

Pour 2 €, prix de mon achat, ça le vaut.
JE regrette quand même: les graphismes limités, l'absence d'un scénar et le trailer steam pas à jour.
Si vous êtes un malade du TD comme moi, c'est bien, mais ça ne convertira pas les frileux ou les néophytes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136763678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1468549099}
review:
A fun little tower defense game with an interesting premise but not worth the $8 asking price. Buy it when it's on sale for 75% off like I did and you won't feel bad at all. I mean, it's pretty much a slightly more polished Kongregate game and honestly, there are free Kongregate games that are actually more in-depth and flat out more fun to play. I can't write the game off completely because I did get 5 hours worth of play out of it. But honestly it was more because I truly wanted to like the game more than I did because it is sort of an interesting take on tower defense style games and it is fun for a while as you progress and unlock new characters and perks.

My biggest gripe with the game is the fact that it's called Bardbarian and the entire premise is based around you controlling the Bard (essentially a pied-piper type character) and everything about the game revolves around music and, well, being a bard. However, the soundtrack is so depressingly lacking, it basically becomes little more than background hum if you play it for any real length of time. Sadly, the ONE song that is the entire soundtrack is actually quite decent. But it's one freaking song. And not even really a complete song but a riff on a loop. I honestly feel that if they were more inventive with the soundtrack and how it played into the game, the $8 asking price would not only have been reasonable, but it would have been a deal. IMO, games like this live and die by their soundtrack and sadly this game died with it's.

The overall gameplay is extremely satisfactory for a casual tower defense, the key word here being casual. I mean, you don't aim, you don't shoot anything, there is no placement of towers, you basically weave your band of hand-chosen characters, each with their pros and cons, through waves of increasingly difficult levels. That is, once you start progressing and unlocking more characters with increasingly different character traits. This may sound like an extreme bore but it really is balanced when it comes to difficulty and satisfaction as you unlock new characters and/or perks. Sure, you're only essentially bobbing and weaving and leading your charges into battle but, it's really not as easy as it sounds and there is a real emphasis on choosing your characters and perks wisely.

I'm giving this a recommend overall but at a warning that I honestly don't think it's worth the retail price. Put it on your wishlist and catch it on sale. I paid $1.99 during the Summer Sale and feel like I certainly got my money's worth for that price. I certainly don't mind supporting indie devs, especially when they release truly enjoyable content, but at some point, I have to ask myself if the price is worth the product when there are so many similar titles out there that you can play 100% free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041949592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 605, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1467303966}
review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Tower defence   game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

You can play this game Fullscreen or windowed mode.
There are some other Languages.
You are able to change your controls on the keyboard.
You can only turn off the Sound and music. There is no Volume bar.
You can play this game with a xbox controller.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

You are playing with a barbarian that is only able to move around. He can't attack enemies by hisself but he is able to call his friends or units. You are walking around and the units are following you, You can pick up enemy gold if they has been killed and you need to dodge their attacks to avoid damage. Most of the units are surrounding around you but you and them can still take damage. If one of your units has been destroyed, they will drop some of the musical notes. Musical notes are needed to call units. You will get musical notes overtime or sometimes from enemy drops. You can spend gold to upgrade your hero, Units or even town supplies. You are somewhat dependant on your units, because the only thing that you are able to do is walking around. Your units will upgrade themself during waves but these are only temporary. There is a small map on the top, where you can see enemy movement. There are 2 other game modes. Called survival and escape. If playing Escape, you will have 1 health and you run as much as you can on the right side of the screen. Avoiding enemy bullets and grabbing gold on your way. 

There is a ingame tutorial.
Upgrade Shop (Units/Hero/Town).
Has small map on the top.
Has 2 different game modes. (Survival mode and escape)
Units upgrade themself during waves.
You can Pause during waves.
Game progression feels slow. (upgrading and clearing waves).
VERY Dependant on ur units and your units are a bit MEH in term of play.
Super Grinding.
Game Goes too slow and makes it Semi-Boring

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Some Easter eggs. Like Characters from different games.
Playing Challenges could spoil some locked units or enemies, as you can use and see them.

-------------------

I Give this game a 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198067227433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1474649673}
review:
Short: Flash game like. Lot of farming. Fun for some time. Wait for sale.

This game is basically a flash game, but a good one. You destroy waves of incoming enemies before they reach the town crystal (deliberate silliness). You cannot attack monsters directly, though: you have to chant out a small band of warriors which will follow you closely. The goal is to dodge projectiles, while coming close enough the enemies so that your soldiers can kill them. Which means: you basically only have to move. Simplistic, but it proves efficiently entertaining.

Of course, as it has a flash game mechanics, you won't be able to go very far on your first run, but you win money with which you can upgrade yourself and your followers (as well as diverse features). Everything is quite basic, so do not expect much. It is fun, though, even if you have to repeat endlessly the same few waves. There is some diversity among the monsters, and a good choice of different followers. Developers have surely been imaginative on that side. 

It gets boring after a few hours of gameplay, alas. Plus, the additional modes (survival and run) are most boring. In the survival mode, you can not do anything but dodge every foes for entire long minutes. Running is slow and devoid of any interest. Only the main game mode is worth playing; the other two are for achievements only. 

Do not spend more than 3 euros/dollars in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038862043', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1624311441}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014296958', 'num_games_owned': 2476, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1451830279}
review:
Extremely fun game and several hours of playtime guaranteed. 
The graphics are a bit like Castle Crashers and the game mechanics feel similar as well. I played this game from start to finish with my xbox 360 controller and it worked flawless with the game. 

The replay value is 'meh' since you can unlock more characters to assist you and you can try new tactics to finish the game faster, but nothing you'd want to play weeks on end. There's also the challenge levels, which are pretty alright, but the most fun for me was the actual campaign.

If the current pricetag of 8 euro is too steep for you, I would definitely recommend getting it during a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144398171', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1461949942}
review:
Bardbarian é um game indie lançado no ano de 2014 pela TreeFortress Games que traz a mistura dos gêneros aventura, ação, tower defense e estratégia. O game acontece em um ambiente 2D e você comanda uma bárbaro bardo que não ataca apenas faz composições musicais afim de salvar sua cidade do ataque compulsivo de orcs.

O enredo é simples, uma cidade possui uma fonte inesgotável de energia originada de um cristal poderoso e os orcs a fim de derrotar e tomar conta do reino, pois querem destruir esse cristal. A partir daí o bardo bárbaro é escalado para a missão de através de suas canções, comandar as tropas e evitar a invasão orc.

O jogo possui uma jogabilidade extremamente simples, você utiliza-se de notas musicais para criar suas unidades e deve movimentar-se próximo aos orcs para que elas ataquem, o jogo é bem frenético e muito rápido, o segredo dele é movimentar-se a todo o momento, a cada horda de orcs superadas você adquire recompensas em ouro que por sua vez serão utilizados para comprar melhorias para você, suas tropas e sua cidade além de novos armamentos e novos tipos de unidades. Após algum tempo o jogo torna-se muito repetitivo, principalmente que quando você morre é obrigado a recomeçar todas as hordas.

Para compor a trilha sonora notamos a forte influência do rock tanto na música que acompanha o momento da batalha quanto os solos de invocação de unidades, o grande problema aqui é a repetitividade da música, pois não são muitas que embalam a aventura.

Os gráficos são bem desenhados e bem coloridos, são feitos em 2D mais não apresentam uma péssima qualidade, as unidades são bem representadas e alguns detalhes de movimentação e ataque são bem feitos, como o jogo é indie acredito que não houve um grande investimento, porém no quesito gráfico o game não deixa a desejar.

Bardbarian é um indie casual, uma boa pedida para algumas horas de distração, o game é bastante desafiador mais a falta de conteúdo diferenciado não permite que o game tenha uma grande vida útil. O game é divertido e vale a pena conferir em uma promoção, pois pode ser um bom nome para ser colocado em prática naquela jogatina rápida.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991193895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1543245704}
review:
Exelent jeu, mise à par la traduction Française qui reste un peu à désirer, mais n'oublion pas que c'est un jeu indé.
Le jeu me plaît bien, pas trop gourment et donc je peux y jouer sur n'importe quelle ordi. Quand je dois attendre devant mon PC (rendu vidéo, etc...) le jeu me permet de patienter tranquillement. Voilà en gros pour 8€ c'est parfait.

review: mobile port, a simple twist on tower defense with mobile defend units and upgrade. to slow for me, and units can only be uppgraded when you die. so you need to die to get far in to the game. making you replay boring maps so you can get the money to continue where you left off. for me this is way to slow and to much repetition.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967817775', 'num_games_owned': 2072, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1398246108}
review: As someone who buys a lot of game bundles I tend to jump into numerous indie titles site unseen, something that usually ends poorly. Bardbarian however was a pleasant surprise, a game that takes two genres I'm usually lukewarm on (tower defense and shumps) and manges to combine them in a way that I found super addictive. It does get a bit grindy towards the end, but I found the mechanics entertaining enough in their own right that I never felt too bored. The charming art-style was a big plus as well. An easy reccomendation for anyone looking for something to tackle in bite-size chunks (it's a great 15 minute break game) and for the achivement hunters out there, they're a pretty easy 100%.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999920602', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 623, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1547334927}
review: This is a 2D defense game where you hire minions to follow you around and kill things on your behalf. I completed it in one sitting; it’s got great animations, some original mechanics and nice humour. The upgrades system works well & the difficulty curve is spot on - except for perhaps the last boss which took inordinately longer than everything else. Once I’d maxed out my wizards it was just a case of not getting one-shot by the Beholders for the last 3 waves of the game. Not sure how I would have completed it without their sniper knockback! Only other criticism is the music; it’s good - but only one 30 second clip on a loop got old really quickly considering the game is about 5 hours long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198288635573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1463895569}
review:
原本是一款手游戏作品，手柄支持的不错，打起来挺爽快的，类型挺独特，结合了塔防和弹幕（这个是主要），还有些RPG元素。然而在PC上的感觉就是缺乏内容，玩了几小时后就觉得这是一款偶尔拿来消磨时间的游戏，音乐也很少，背景乐貌似就只有宣传视频里那首……

不过，在前两三小时内仍旧很愉快，推荐玩到把卡都掉了；P

author: {'steamid': '76561198004603031', 'num_games_owned': 1412, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1427413862}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991112921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1465675215}
review: This game is actually pretty fun and fairly unique. It combines bullet hell, tower defense, and RPG elements in a pretty compelling way. So why the thumbs down, you ask? Well, this version of the game is priced higher than it should be. First off, the claim of "Steam exclusive" characters in this version is completely false. Don't believe me? Download the FREE version on Google Play or the App Store and see for yourself. The only item that costs money in the free (and virtually identical) version is the golden axe, which is obtained with in game currency in this version but costs only $3 in the free tablet/smartphone version. This game is normally priced at $8 and thus, I cannot recommend it unless you get it on sale (for controller support, I suppose). However, tablet controls are not bad and you can even play it on an emulator if you don't have a tablet. So, skip this version unless you happen to see it for at least 50% off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030893104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1398230960}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198062448641', 'num_games_owned': 2313, 'num_reviews': 305, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1423402799}
review:
[h1]От рассвета до заката по аккордам тимой раков[/h1]

...лучник еще спрашивал, выживет ли из нас хоть кто-нибудь, кроме меня. Я ему сыграл немного на гитаре, он вроде успокоился, лучше целиться стал. Маги чего-то шептались за спиной ближе к полудню, кажется жрать хотели, но хоть исправно колдовали, спасибо творцам. Но вот пока мечники пытались забить огра, одна маленькая сволочь пробралась мимо офиса создателей этой игры и начала шпарить по моему, мать вашу, фонтану! Нееееет, так дела не делаются. Быстренько откумекали этого гоблина, а уже почти вечер наступил. Мдааа, веселье ближе к ночи, устрою я всем концерт на своей мега-гитаре, покажу свою Брутальную легенду, ибо нефиг. Динозаврами они меня пугать будут, пфе. У меня в союзниках Октопус и мать его Мясной пацан есть! Лошары, не на того барда напали.

Черт, уже ночь, как же жрать-то охота...

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32313063/] Куратор	[/url]

Ставьте лайк, подписывайтесь на кураторскую страничку и ищите новое в играх!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054902790', 'num_games_owned': 864, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1397916254}
review:
Nous sommes en présence d'un jeu plutôt intéressant et accrocheur. Avec un Gameplay simple et une direction artistique soignée sans parler d'une excellente bande son, on peut féliciter le travail apporté à ce petit jeu. Il est cependant dommage que les niveaux semblent vides et que le mode histoire ne soit pas bien long même si le New Game+ ainsi que les modes survie et infini rallongent un peu la durée de vie. A savoir qu'il existe une version de ce jeu en Free-to-play sur Android. Bien que répétitif il s'agit là d'une bonne pioche pour qui aime les petits jeux alliant les genres avec ici un mélange de Shoot'em up, Tower Defense et RPG plutôt réussi.

Test complet : http://aquab0n.fr/2014/06/test-bardbarian.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1460432020}
review:
[i]Bardbarian[/i] is an evade-'em-up game.  You play an overmuscled Conan figure who has decided that he's sick of hacking foes to death and only wants to play music, which might be a more noble attitude if his village wasn't presently under siege by the usual forces of darkness.  Thankfully, your music (plus money, earned by killing enemies) can inspire less-squeamish types to follow you around and do the dirty work for you.  Strategy revolves around getting close enough to enemies for your followers to attack them, but still avoiding enemy fire, and recruiting and upgrading an effective mix of followers.

This game doesn't have much depth, it isn't all that compelling, and probably won't hold your interest very long, but it's just different enough from typical games to make it a good short-term casual game.  If your expectations are modest, it will meet them -- that's about all it's fair to ask from a casual game like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129787527', 'num_games_owned': 280, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1449399653}
review:
A fun game to play but I would recomend playing this with a controler because keyboard controls are usable but arn't ideal. I can see people being able to complete this in a day or two however it still offers additional gamemodes once you complete the story. Also playable really well with the steam remote with the circle pads working really well with this game. The concept of the game is something many would enjoy and the massive choice of upgrades makes it addictive. I think the achievements and thier names are great and there are a few easter eggs in the game that are fun too look around the game and find. Overall this game is worth the money you payed for it and you should buy it.

[strike] buy it for everyone ever! [/strike]
